parameters.name: R&D Spec/Capability/Means
parameters.description: This parameter refers to all activities related to conceptualizing, trialing, beta-testing, verifying, and validating novel products, processes, or services before they are finalized and offered to customers. It encompasses both tangible and intangible elements, including knowledge, emotional qualities, physical artefacts, and functional services.

parameters.name: R&D Cost
parameters.description: The financial resources needed to conduct research and development activities.

parameters.name: R&D Time
parameters.description: The duration required to complete research and development activities.

parameters.name: R&D Risk
parameters.description: The probability and potential impact of unforeseen challenges or failures during research and development.

parameters.name: R&D Interfaces
parameters.description: The interactions and dependencies between different parts or teams involved in research and development.

parameters.name: Production Spec/Capability/Means
parameters.description: The quality, efficiency, and resources needed to produce the final product, process, or service.

parameters.name: Production Cost
parameters.description: The financial resources required to manufacture the final product, process, or service.

parameters.name: Production Time
parameters.description: The duration needed to manufacture the final product, process, or service.

inventive_principles.name: Segmentation
inventive_principles.description: Divide an object or system into independent parts.
examples: Splitting a large task into smaller, manageable sub-tasks.
Separating components of a product for easier assembly and repair.

inventive_principles.name: Taking Out
inventive_principles.description: Remove a part or element that is unnecessary or harmful.
examples: Removing unnecessary features from a software application to simplify its interface.
Eliminating a component that causes friction in a mechanical system.

inventive_principles.name: Local Quality
inventive_principles.description: Change the local quality of an object or system.
examples: Using different materials or processes in specific areas of a product to improve its performance.
Modifying the design of a component to make it more resistant to wear and tear.

inventive_principles.name: Asymmetry
inventive_principles.description: Make an object or system asymmetric.
examples: Designing an asymmetrical airfoil to reduce drag.
Using different-sized wheels on a vehicle to improve stability.

inventive_principles.name: Merging
inventive_principles.description: Combine similar or identical objects or systems.
examples: Merging two separate software programs into a single integrated system.
Combining two different manufacturing processes to reduce production time.

inventive_principles.name: Universality
inventive_principles.description: Make a part or system multi-functional.
examples: Designing a tool that can perform multiple tasks.
Creating a software application that can be used on different platforms.

inventive_principles.name: Nesting
inventive_principles.description: Place one object inside another.
examples: Designing a retractable antenna that fits inside a small space.
Using nested containers to reduce packaging waste.

inventive_principles.name: Counterweight
inventive_principles.description: Add a counterweight to an object or system to balance it.
examples: Using a counterweight to stabilize a crane.
Adding a counterbalance to a door to make it easier to open.

inventive_principles.name: Preliminary Action
inventive_principles.description: Perform a preliminary action to prepare an object or system for its intended use.
examples: Pre-heating a furnace before casting a metal part.
Pre-loading a spring to improve its performance.

inventive_principles.name: Prior Action
inventive_principles.description: Carry out an action before the main process.
examples: Performing a pre-flight check before taking off in an airplane.
Using a primer to improve the adhesion of paint.

inventive_principles.name: Beforehand Cushion
inventive_principles.description: Create a buffer or cushion to prevent damage or failure.
examples: Using a shock absorber to absorb impacts.
Building a safety margin into a product to account for variations in manufacturing.

inventive_principles.name: Equi-action
inventive_principles.description: Perform actions simultaneously or in a coordinated manner.
examples: Using a two-handed operation to increase efficiency.
Synchronizing the movements of multiple robots in a manufacturing process.

inventive_principles.name: Other Dimension
inventive_principles.description: Move an object or system into another dimension.
examples: Using a multi-layer design to increase the storage capacity of a product.
Transferring data to a cloud-based server to improve accessibility.

inventive_principles.name: Spheroidality
inventive_principles.description: Change the shape of an object or system to a sphere.
examples: Using spherical bearings to reduce friction.
Designing a spherical tank to maximize storage capacity.

inventive_principles.name: Dynamicity
inventive_principles.description: Make an object or system dynamic.
examples: Using a variable-speed motor to control the speed of a machine.
Designing a self-adjusting mechanism to compensate for wear and tear.

inventive_principles.name: Partial or Excessive Action
inventive_principles.description: Perform an action partially or excessively.
examples: Using a partial cut to reduce the weight of a component.
Applying an excessive force to break a material.

inventive_principles.name: Another Dimension
inventive_principles.description: Change the direction of action or movement.
examples: Using a vertical instead of a horizontal orientation to save space.
Changing the direction of flow in a fluid system.

inventive_principles.name: Mechanical Vibration
inventive_principles.description: Introduce mechanical vibration or oscillation.
examples: Using a vibrating screen to separate materials.
Applying vibration to a welding process to improve the quality of the weld.

inventive_principles.name: Periodic Action
inventive_principles.description: Perform an action periodically or intermittently.
examples: Using a pulsed laser to cut or engrave materials.
Applying a periodic force to a system to maintain its stability.

inventive_principles.name: Continuity of Useful Action
inventive_principles.description: Make an action continuous or uninterrupted.
examples: Using a continuous conveyor belt to move materials.
Designing a self-cleaning system to prevent buildup of dirt.

inventive_principles.name: Rushing Through
inventive_principles.description: Perform an action at high speed.
examples: Using a high-speed press to form a metal part.
Applying a rapid pulse of energy to a system.

inventive_principles.name: Convert to a Mechanical System
inventive_principles.description: Convert a non-mechanical system to a mechanical one.
examples: Using a robotic arm to perform a task that was previously done manually.
Automating a process that was previously done manually.

inventive_principles.name: Feedback
inventive_principles.description: Introduce feedback into a system to control its behavior.
examples: Using a thermostat to regulate the temperature of a room.
Introducing feedback into a manufacturing process to ensure quality control.

inventive_principles.name: Intermediary
inventive_principles.description: Use an intermediary object or system.
examples: Using a tool to perform a task that is difficult or impossible to do by hand.
Introducing a mediator to resolve a conflict between two parties.

inventive_principles.name: Self-Service
inventive_principles.description: Make an object or system self-servicing.
examples: Designing a self-cleaning oven.
Creating a software application that automatically updates itself.

inventive_principles.name: Copying
inventive_principles.description: Copy a part or element of an object or system.
examples: Using a template to create multiple identical parts.
Replicating a successful design.

inventive_principles.name: Cheap Disposable
inventive_principles.description: Make an object or system disposable and inexpensive.
examples: Using disposable cups or plates to reduce cleanup.
Producing a product with a low cost of manufacture.

inventive_principles.name: Replace Mechanical System
inventive_principles.description: Replace a mechanical system with a non-mechanical one.
examples: Using a software program to control a machine.
Replacing a mechanical valve with a digital one.

inventive_principles.name: Pneumatics and Hydraulics
inventive_principles.description: Use pneumatics or hydraulics.
examples: Using a pneumatic actuator to move a heavy object.
Utilizing hydraulics to power a crane.

inventive_principles.name: Flexible Shells and Thin Films
inventive_principles.description: Use flexible shells and thin films.
examples: Using a flexible membrane to seal a container.
Applying a thin film to a surface to protect it.

inventive_principles.name: Porous Materials
inventive_principles.description: Use porous materials.
examples: Using a filter to remove impurities from a liquid.
Designing a porous material to absorb moisture.

inventive_principles.name: Changing Color
inventive_principles.description: Change the color of an object or system.
examples: Using color to improve the visibility of a product.
Changing the color of a surface to reflect more or less heat.

inventive_principles.name: Homogeneity
inventive_principles.description: Make an object or system homogeneous.
examples: Using a single material to manufacture a product.
Creating a uniform surface to reduce friction.

inventive_principles.name: Discarding and Recycling
inventive_principles.description: Discard or recycle parts or elements of an object or system.
examples: Using a reusable container instead of a disposable one.
Recycling materials to reduce waste.

inventive_principles.name: Parameter Changes
inventive_principles.description: Change the parameter of an object or system.
examples: Changing the size or shape of a component to improve its performance.
Adjusting the operating temperature or pressure of a system.

inventive_principles.name: Phase Transition
inventive_principles.description: Use a phase transition.
examples: Using a change in temperature to melt or solidify a material.
Utilizing a change in pressure to cause a gas to condense.

inventive_principles.name: Thermal Expansion
inventive_principles.description: Use thermal expansion or contraction.
examples: Using a bimetallic strip to control a thermostat.
Utilizing thermal expansion to create a seal.

inventive_principles.name: Strong Oxidants
inventive_principles.description: Use strong oxidants.
examples: Using oxygen to accelerate a combustion process.
Utilizing ozone to disinfect a surface.

inventive_principles.name: Inert Atmosphere
inventive_principles.description: Use an inert atmosphere.
examples: Using nitrogen to prevent oxidation of a material.
Creating an inert environment to prevent contamination.

inventive_principles.name: Composite Materials
inventive_principles.description: Use composite materials.
examples: Using fiberglass to create a lightweight and strong material.
Combining different materials to create a material with specific properties.
